data.text:
It's @threadapalooza Day! 

I'll be writing a 100-tweet thread about living a great life.

From the outset, it's important to address the most common misconception about living a great life, which makes it impossible to attain.

Let's go!

1. Alan Watts made the important observation that the analogy we use to describe life is that of a journey, with a destination we're striving to reach. But he says this is a faulty analogy.

Life is not a journey but a dance and the point is to enjoy the experience, here and now.

2. The "Journey Mindset" creates a lot of distance between where we are and the life we want. We have to do things, achieve things, own things that we don't currently do, have done, or have. 

By definition, a great life is not here, but there (where we want to be).

3. Even if we DO achieve everything we set out to achieve, life doesn't end there. So what do we do next? 

We pick another destination to strive for, never feeling accomplished or satisfied where we are. The great life is only a mirage we can never reach (with this approach).

4. The Journey Mindset sets us up for the sense of lack and frustration with being here and not there. The gap robs us of joy "here" and offers dissatisfaction "there".

I don't know about you, but that doesn't sound like a great life to me.

What's the alternative?

5. To be clear: there's nothing wrong with striving for things you don't currently have, but how do you see your life where you are? 

Are you experiencing joy? Are you grateful for the things you have? Do you love yourself for who you are? Are you celebrating your progress?

6. The Dance Mindset allows you to embrace and find joy in the present. It doesn't mean you can't strive for things, but it brings about an everyday cheerfulness that's not dependent on your relationship with your pursuit.

You can want things and still enjoy the here and now.

7. Living a great life is an equation. My numbers may not be precise, but it's something along the following lines:

60% how you see the world (and your place in it)

20% doing things within your means and abilities

20% pursuing things you currently can't have

8. There is a saying by Imam Al-Sadiq: "Love of this world* is like drinking sea water. The more the thirsty drinks from it the thirstier he gets until it kills him."

The wealthy want to be wealthier & the famous more famous.

* This can mean materialistic pursuits

9. If we can never be content with what we have, we can never be happy or satisfied. And if greatness is measured by something else (not happiness, joy, satisfaction), then what is it that we are trying to accomplish?

What's the definition of a "great" life that we're seeking?

10. Not knowing what "great" even means would be committing 2 mistakes at once: deciding on a journey without a clear destination.

Where we end up may not be so great. In fact, the effort we put in might be taking us further away from what a great life truly is.

11. What if a great life isn't about us being happy but about making others happy?

Contributing to the lives of others is certainly a part of a great life, and we'll look at some caveats later. Besides, we don't want anyone feeling guilty for BEING happy when others are not.

12. People have a weird relationship with "selfishness" that makes it near impossible to be happy:

- Seeking your own happiness is selfish (bad)
- Making other people happy is selfless (good)
- Being happy for what others have done for you is selfish (bad)

How can we be happy?!

13. There's a difference between caring for yourself and being self-centered.

Caring for yourself is great. You should value your own happiness and well-being.

NOT caring for others limits your own capacity to feel happy and finding ways to be happy.

14. Your happiness and the happiness of others aren't mutually exclusive. You can seek to be happy AND make others happy.

Being happy makes others happier.

Helping others be happy will make you happier. 

Being surrounded by happier people will make us all happier.

15. A great life is about both being happy AND contributing to the happiness of others.

One doesn't compromise the other.

Both can reinforce and amplify each other.

And this requires understanding what makes us and others happy.

16. Many people (especially young adults) panic at the thought of not knowing what makes them happy or not having something figured out in life yet. They assume they're falling behind and others have already found the answers to the big questions in life.

#laughsInAdult

17. The truth is: you don't have to have figured things out to be happy or to lead a great life.

Knowing that you haven't figured things out is a valuable realization that reveals what you should do next: figure things out.

And as @marieforleo says: Everything is figureoutable.

18. The same existential angst can creep up in different stages of our lives. 

We don't know what career path to take or what business to start or what relationship to commit to & we panic for not knowing the answer.

Knowing that we don't know the answer is part of the answer.

19. As @RyanHoliday (inspired by Marcus Aurelius) says: "The obstacle is the way."

Knowing that you don't know makes your job a lot easier. Find out:

- What you need to learn
- What variables you need to consider
- What your preferences are
- What actions you will take

20. Exploration is a thing. Figuring things out is a thing.

The idea that you need to know the answer before gaining the knowledge is a mental trap that gets in the way of living a great life.

Before you know, you don't. Before you can, you can't.

Accept these facts of life

21. [INTERLUDE]

I'll be back with the rest of the thread after a short break from writing. There's a lot more to cover & we've only touched the surface!

We're going to look into 7 life areas that make up our lives, the importance of progress, & why self-love is so critical.

22. So far we looked at the importance of shifting from the "life is a journey" perspective (with a goal being there, not here) to the "life is a dance" perspective (with the goal being here, not there).

We also touched on the need to define what a great life is.

23. So what IS a great life? What makes it great? And what does it involve?

As human beings we have a variety of needs. Satisfying one need while ignoring the rest ultimately leads to failure and dissatisfaction, no matter how great the accomplishment in a single domain.

24. Unfortunately, many people are fixated on a specific goal (usually to be rich and/or famous), while ignoring all else.

While success in a single domain is possible, neglecting other domains tends to compromise the effort we put in that domain. 

I'll elaborate...

25. If you want to make a lot of money, this usually requires creativity and productivity, both of which require focus and energy.

If you're neglecting your health (what you eat, how well you sleep, and how much you move), are you operating at your best? Can you do better?

26. You can amplify your creativity, productivity, and the opportunities that come your way by nurturing your relationships. 

So if you're neglecting your relationships and aren't surrounding yourself with great people, are you helping or harming your pursuit of money?

27. I'm not even talking about the dissatisfaction that will eventually come when lots of money can leave you feeling empty.

To get better results at wealth creation, you need the help of other life areas besides your Professional (work) life area.

28. Therefore, to succeed within a single life area requires all life areas & a great life involves catering for all life areas on an ongoing basis.

So what are the life areas?

What does success look like in each?

And how can you make progress with all of them, where you are?

29. The 7 life areas that make up our lives are:

- Spiritual
- Intellectual
- Psychological
- Social
- Professional
- Recreational
- Physical

Feel free to use different words to refer to each life area, but the underlying needs are ultimately the same.

30. I'll explain what each life area is & what it involves, but I can't define what success looks like for you within each life area, nor do I know where you are in life to suggest what you can do next.

But I'll give tips at the end on how to make progress balancing them all.

31. Your Spiritual Life Area

This involves the purpose that guides your life and the legacy you wish to leave behind. It's the cause that's greater than your self and your day-to-day existence.

It can infuse meaning in everything you do. It's not separate from other life areas.

32. You can be spiritual in a religious way or a secular way. But either way, it's important to honor the Truth and to respect your own capacity to think.

Harmony between your Spiritual & Intellectual life areas is crucial. Otherwise, they'll compromise each other.

33. This life area also includes your moral values, which determine how you make decisions in life. 

Lack of clarity about your values (what matters most to you and what your red flags are) can lead to a great deal of doubt and confusion in other life areas.

34. And BAD moral values can also have extremely negative consequences, be it on a personal, social, or global level.

Terrorists don't lack morals. They have strong convictions in bad morals.

Bad people usually don't realize that they're bad. They often think they're great.

35. You could be experiencing a great deal of guilt over something you've done because you're clinging to a moral value that's not in harmony with human well-being.

If you think pursuing your happiness is selfish &, therefore, evil, it can get in the way of living a great life.

36. "What's my purpose in life?" is a question that can lead to an existential crisis at any age, and it often has an implicit assumption of a purpose to DISCOVER and not a purpose to DECIDE on.

In other words: there is only one right answer, and you have to figure that out.

37. Your purpose in life is a cause or contribution you care about & wish to dedicate time, effort, & attention to.

That's it.

In many cases, it's a cause that will outlive you and won't be resolved/reached in your life time. You're simply playing your part in the grand scheme.

38. You don't even have to decide on a single purpose for your entire life. You can dedicate a number of years to a cause then move to something else. 

What matters is that you make a contribution to something you care about & you have conviction in what you're currently doing.

39. Even within a religious context of a God creating us and having a reason for creating us, you can still believe there's space for you to DECIDE on your purpose.

Most religions promote a connection with God, being a good person, and serving others. HOW you serve is up to you.

40. Many, MANY people have to deal with a lot of spiritual baggage as a result of an upbringing that forced religious convictions on them. 

The path is already full of obstacles, with the need to heal from trauma and re-discover one's convictions and values.

41. [INTERLUDE]

Will be back after a break to cover the other 6 life areas and how to find the right "blend" of balance between all life areas where you are, with what you have, in order to make progress in your life.

Back soon*!

*-ish

42. Before I jump to the next life area (Psychological), I forgot to mention that political activism can be a spiritual pursuit when you're working for a cause that's greater than you, but has a common pitfall of fighting for "bad morals" or seeking power instead of fairness.

43. In politics, there's a mix of the Spiritual, Intellectual (and often it's the ideological), Psychological (the sense of extended social identity), and Social (caring for one's tribe).

Introspection is needed for us to evaluate our vision, values, and intentions.

Next up...

44. Your Intellectual Life Area

It involves methods of learning, topics you're learning about, skills you're developing, & your cognitive abilities.

The goal is to develop the level of proficiency you want in the areas you want, both in knowing (theory) & doing (practice).

45. Learning boils down to constructing a mental model of the world. The goal is for the model to be as expansive as it can be (which requires broad learning), as detailed it can be (deep learning), and as accurate as possible (requiring critical thinking & unlearning).

46. Knowledge is when your mental model matches reality. What we hold to be true but isn't is opinion. 

If we cling to something as true when it isn't, that's dogma.

Learning requires the humility to admit when we're wrong & to reconstruct the parts of our model that are wrong.

47. It's possible for our models to be wrong on a fundamental (worldview) level, or we can be wrong about specific topics and factoids (forgetting a name or a particular date).

Many people resist changes in their worldview because it robs them of their sense of certainty.

48. However, temporary doubt and skepticism should be welcome steps towards a better, more accurate understanding of the world.

No one gains anything by clinging to an idea that isn't true. It's not a virtue to believe in something & refusing to look at alternative perspectives.

49. By far the biggest obstacles in learning have nothing to do with our cognitive/intellectual abilities and everything to do with our psychology.

When learning something new we can feel intimidated & not learn.

When we become experts, our pride can prevent us from unlearning.

50. Psychology plays a big part in our learning and it's worth acknowledging that role to address the obstacles that can prevent us from learning properly.

Even what looks like learning (such as note-taking) can be a form of procrastination to avoid the actual learning we need.

51. We learn best by doing, and doing can be intimidating. 

We're afraid of failure, making mistakes, or looking foolish. But by accepting the fact that we don't know before we do and can't before we can, we give ourselves room to learn.

Mistakes are a sign of learning.

52. Not only do we want an accurate mental model, but we want to be able to navigate it masterfully to achieve the results we want.

This navigation involves COMMUNICATING what we know and APPLYING what we know. Both are valuable expressions of our learning.

53. There's a lot more to mention about this life area, but I'll conclude this section with a note on reality and intellectual fragmentation: many people hold disparate factoids in their minds and are unable to see the connections (and contradictions) between the ideas they hold.

54. It's important to recognize reality as the benchmark to our learning and how the facts connect in reality. In fact, everything is (eventually) connected at some point.

There is no such thing as siloed disciplines. Everything is connected to everything else.

55. Final final note: you may be wondering where creativity comes into this if reality is the benchmark. Creativity, in art and technology, is fueled by knowledge, but not limited to it.

Knowing the constraints in reality and developing concepts helps us play with concepts.

56. There is no creative thought that wasn't inspired by a fact. It just plays with the facts in ways that don't exist in reality but can be imagined and then created, whether as an art piece or a practical device for us to use.

Knowledge inspires creativity.

57. As Francis Bacon says: "Nature, to be commanded, must be obeyed."

This is especially true of technology. To create something that doesn't yet exist requires understanding the way reality functions & how the properties of the materials we have can be used to our advantage.

58. Final final final note (I'm a designer. Designers should know this is common practice in our field ðŸ¤£): I already mentioned the importance of unlearning to revise and refine our understanding of the world.

Critical thinking is a critical skill for this very reason.

59. We need to be aware of our own mental BIASES (ways we try to save time and effort to reach a conclusion to take action) and logical FALLACIES (ways we incorrectly connect ideas together. A common example is the confusion between causation and correlation).

60. Being aware of biases and fallacies allows us to apply vigilance in accepting new ideas as true, as well as the ability to revise our existing beliefs (what has already been added to our mental model but may not be an accurate reflection of reality).

61. [INTERLUDE]

I'll continue writing, but will need some time before I publish the next batch of tweets. I was going to add a final x4 note to talk about the scientific method, but I have to move on to other life areas & I ONLY have 100 tweets in this @threadapalooza thread. ðŸ˜‚

62. Your Psychological Life Area

You can think of this life area as involving 3 primary areas: Mindset, Ego, and Emotions (M.E.E. for short).

Mindset is your mental attitude towards life and the way you handle the challenges you face in it. Does it empower you or cripple you?

63. Notice what you say to yourself about your life and you'll understand what your mindset is. 

"This always happens to me"

"Why does this happen to me?"

"I never get what I want."

All these statements are expressions of a defeatist (and entitled) mindset. Watch out!

64. You want to cultivate a mindset that's both true and empowering, which requires acknowledging and focusing on the right thing.

You can acknowledge your weaknesses without defining your identity by them.

You can focus on your strengths and make the most of them.

65. Mindset plays a HUUUUUGE role in your life and your potential to live a great life. Your life is not what happens to you but how you interpret it.

You can have all the ingredients for a great life but fail to see them, and end up dying of starvation. Focus on what matters.

66. I find Stoic philosophy to be incredibly useful in developing the right attitude towards life by accepting what is and doing what's in my capacity to change, without feeling frustrated by what happens to me. 

I accept reality as it is and adjust my expectations accordingly.

67. This doesn't mean I LOWER my expectations. Being realistic doesn't mean being pessimistic. Far from it. How you seen what humans have accomplished and the advancements we have made?

If you haven't, then maybe you're focusing on the wrong things. ðŸ˜œ

There's a lot we can do.

68. Positive change IS possible, but we need to go about it the right way. Lamenting the state of the world doesn't change the state of the world. Attacking people for how they are right now only makes them put their guard up.

We need to be patient and do the right things.

69. I also find Rudyard Kipling's poem "If" very inspiring in dealing with adversities and not getting sucked into negative thinking.

Cultivating an empowering mindset requires practice and gentle guidance. You don't want to push yourself too hard.

https://t.co/3XfEod2Xns

70. And speaking of your"self", let's move on to the next dimension of the Psychological life area: Ego.

It's important to make a distinction between SELF-IMAGE & SELF. 

The first is based on our personal impression of ourselves and how others perceive us. It's NOT who we are.

71. It's primarily based on the past and clinging to it leads to a "fixed mindset" and following a script without acknowledging our ability to move beyond this character profile of ourselves.

Who YOU are and your SELF has the quality to redefine itself and grow in any direction.

72. You are not your past. You are not who you think you are. You are not defined by how others see you and think of you.

You can drastically transform your life by letting go of the ego that's holding you back. 

You can change your personality & attitude with a single choice.

73. Last but not least*, we come to our emotions.

Just like mindset, emotions define our life experience. They play a major role in our ability to achieve a great life, both in how we experience life & what we achieve in it.

* In this life area, I mean. We have FOUR more to go!

74. Think of fear, anxiety, overwhelm, depression, intimidation, and so on. 

Not only are these things we don't want to experience, but they get in the way of us accomplishing the great things we want to accomplish.

Knowing how to deal with our emotions is vitally important.

75. Unfortunately, there is a popular belief that emotions must be experienced and expressed. While there is some truth to this, it fails to address the underlying reasons for our emotions.

Emotions are messengers & negative emotions are positive emotions.

What does this mean?

76. All emotions help us navigate life to make life-affirming decisions. Our negative emotions help us avoid danger and harm to ourselves. They let us know when there's a threat and action is needed.

Simply feeling the emotion doesn't make the threat go away.

77. And the threat isn't always a realistic threat. Failing to address the misconception about the threat means that the same emotions will continue to trigger for the same faulty thinking.

We have to listen to the emotion, as well as address the underlying thought pattern.

78. If the threat is valid, dealing with our emotions, alone, isn't enough. We have to take action to address the threat. Otherwise the same emotions will be constantly triggered because the cause remains unaddressed.

Listen, understand, and take action.

79. You may find it helpful to take a survey of the most common emotions you experience, what emotions you want to experience more/less of, & what changes you can make in your life to experience that shift.

Are you dealing mostly with angry? Stress? Frustration? Disappointment?

80. You may also consider the activities you want to do & goals you want to achieve: what emotions are getting in your way? What mindset do you need to cultivate? Who do you have to become to achieve what you want to achieve?

Change IS possible. You are NOT your self-image.

81. [INTERLUDE]

I have 19 tweets left to cover 4 life areas AND share some parting thoughts. I didn't plan this well. ðŸ™ƒ

82. Your Social Life Area

This covers ALL your relationships across ALL social circles, from the most intimate to the most distant.

ALL relationships can be strengthened by a simple principle: treat others with respect and make them feel good about themselves.

83. It's important to note that strong relationships and a sense of community play a major role in living a great life, both in the well-being we get to experience and the impact we can have on the world.

The more connections you have, the more you can amplify your contribution.

84. What relationships do you currently have? 

What relationships are you currently lacking?

In what ways can you strengthen existing relationships and forge new ones?

What toxic relationships are you currently experiencing that need healing or ending?

85. What social skills do you need to improve to experience healthier relationships?

What habits are getting in the way of strong and enriching relationships? (Hint: phone use around people can have a massive detrimental effect on relations)

What social activities can you do?

86. Your Professional Life Area

This area looks at making & managing money.

You make money by creating value for others.

What the value is, who it's for, & what vehicle you use to create this value (e.g. a job within a corporation, a business, side hustle, etc.) are up to you.

87. It's important to pick a way of making money that is:

- Aligned with your values
- You enjoy doing
- Makes you enough money to support the lifestyle you want
- Plays to your strengths

These are the most fundamental considerations.

88. How you make money involves:

- Creating a valuable product/service
- Making people aware of its existence (marketing)
- Earning people's trust & the desire to have what you offer (selling)
- Establishing systems that make it easier to provide consistent quality (operations)

89. In the vast majority of cases you will need to work with others to deliver the value you want to deliver. Being able to persuade others to work with you and enjoy working with you is fundamental to building a sustainable business (or keeping and thriving at a job).

90. Your Recreational Life Area

Play and rest are ESSENTIAL to a great life and can have a positive impact on other aspects of life, even though you can pursue them for their own joy.

Yes you can make lots of friends playing video games, but the success is in the joy you have.

91. Play can promote creativity, allows for rejuvenation for greater productivity, is a means to connect with others, and may even be the "incubator" for future business opportunities.

The thing you enjoy doing can be the thing that makes you money.

What hobbies do you enjoy?

92. Recreational activities can be:

- Social or solo
- Planned or spontaneous
- Paid or free
- Outside or at home
- Active or passive
- Require learning or you know how to do
- Involve progression or done the same way

There's a wide variety of options to choose from.

93. Your Physical Life Area

This involves how you take care of your physical body, both on the inside (your health) & the outside (how you look).

The 3 main areas of health are: what you eat, how much you move, & how soundly you sleep.

How you look involves fashion & grooming.

94. Many people think that caring about your looks is shallow, but it's only shallow if it's ALL you care about. 

There's a lot you can do to improve your physical well-being, which will have a cascading effect on all other areas of your life, including your confidence & energy.

95. I'd like to end this thread by emphasizing on the need for self-love and self-acceptance. Towards the end of 2019 I felt extremely fragile, seeking the love of others (and their expression of love in the ways I wanted them to express it).

But I was empty inside.

96. I realized I shouldn't depend on others to show me love for me to love myself. I can love myself without any conditions or pre-requisites. In fact, loving myself is the INPUT for a great life, not the OUTPUT of it.

The same is true of happiness (see The Happiness Advantage).

97. I noticed how I talked to myself and chose kindness and caring above all else. 

"Tough love" is rarely loving, and it harms more than it helps. It embeds in us thoughts of insecurity that can cause damage for years to come.

I became at peace with myself and others.

98. 2020 has been a weird and stressful year, but not once did I lose my temper (which was a weekly occurrence in 2019). I got angry a few times, but the feeling quickly subsided because I kept my ego in check and I chose kindness for myself and others.

99. Start with self-love and use it as a foundation to make progress in every life area and throughout your whole life. Notice how you speak to yourself and in what ways can you be kinder. 

Do you feel comfortable saying "I love you" to yourself? If not, work on that.

100. I hope this thread has been useful. Thank you @threadapalooza for the inspiration.

If you'd like to read more about life balance, I've written a book about it (Blend of Balance), as well as 3 other books on habits, productivity, and writing.

https://t.co/EXZg7pgQmK
